dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: One A.M. on a hellish summer night in Spanish Harlem.

dialogues.speaker: 1B FIREFIGHTER
dialogues.text: snores like a chainsaw in the upstairs sleeping quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FAN WHINES as a firefighter channel surfs.

dialogues.speaker: 1D TRUCK BAY
dialogues.text: A rookie firefighter shines chrome on the pumper.

dialogues.speaker: 1E BAY'S OPEN DOORWAY
dialogues.text: A firefighter plays chess with a neighborhood kid.     SA BLASTS from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: 1F OLD FIREHOUSE
dialogues.text: spills light onto a street of aging, neglected buildings as people beat the heat in open windows, on stoops and street corners.

dialogues.speaker: 1G FIREHOUSE DALMATION
dialogues.text: laps water from a dripping hydrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NYFD Lt. GORDY PITT strains as he works the handle of an old-time, hand-cranked ice cream maker. It's a tough job requiring strength, patience and determination. In a nutshell, that's Gordy. Firefighter JUNIOR MONTINE, black Panamanian descent, watches Gordy crank away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear the big news, Lieutenant? It's the twenty-first century.   We got electricity now. Gordy keeps cranking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got these supermarkets, too.   Big places, freezers full o' ice cream. Gordy stops.    Pops the lid.   Spoons out a dollop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up. He sticks the spoon in Junior's mouth.      Junior eats. Junior loves it. Gordy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw the twenty-first century. The FIRE BELL SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone scrambles. The choreography's practiced, automatic. It's achieved without conversation. The channel surfer slides down the fire pole.     He's followed by the man who was upstairs snoring. Junior rips a sheet from the teleprinter. He hands the printout to the snorer, the company's "chauffeur." Feet jam into boots. Yellow trousers are hauled up and hitched with suspenders. Yellow jackets are whipped on. The chauffeur TURNS OVER the PUMPER'S huge MOTOR. Firefighters take their stations on the truck. Headsets go on. As the fire company's lieutenant, Gordy rides shotgun. The chauffeur hands him the printout. As the engine moves out under lights and SIREN, Gordy speaks to the men over the headsets --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second alarm. Multiple dwelling between Third and Lex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENGINE SCREAMS and HONKS through the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAMES ROAR from the upper stories of this slumlord's shitbox. An engine and ladder company are on-scene attacking the fire with hoses. Neighbors gawk. Gordy's engine company arrives. Gordy hits the ground, moves to a battalion chief. The chief's terse orders are drowned out by the NOISE of the EQUIPMENT, fire and men. Gordy moves back to his company, who have already hooked the engine up to water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top story's fully involved. We're supporting inside. Two lines up the stairs. He points to Junior and then to the channel surfer, MIKE SHEA, a veteran firefighter of Irish descent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior and Mike -- He points to the chess player, SAL DIBIASE, another FD veteran, Mediterranean descent, and then to the rookie, RONNIE BOOK, a New York melting pot mutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Sal and Ronnie. The chauffeur, ART WESTPHAL, German-Irish, stays with the engine as Gordy grabs a fire axe and leads his two two- man hose teams into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy and his men charge the stairs dragging the heavy hoses. Rats head past in the opposite direction, deserting the burning building.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD FLOOR
dialogues.text: They meet fire on the third floor. On goes the water. Gordy quickly checks rooms on the floor for occupants, using the axe to open locked doors, then taps Junior and Mike, indicates "up." Begins leading the hose team up the stairwell. Sees something and yells a warning --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stairs're screwed. Hug the wall.

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: They reach the fourth floor.    There's fire everywhere. And then...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They see a FIREFIGHTER from the other company. He has fallen through a gaping hole in the floor of the hallway above. He's pinned under a large section of heavy debris, coughing and screaming for help as fire rages around him. To Junior and Mike --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn the hose on the flames as Gordy moves to the trapped firefighter. Gordy tries lifting the debris, can't budge it. He starts chopping at it with the axe. Chunks of plaster fly as the axe bites again and again. Gordy hacks off a large piece of debris. He levers his axe under the portion still trapping the firefighter. Mike moves to help. Gordy heaves up on the axe. The debris lifts. He heaves harder. It lifts more, until... Mike slides the firefighter out. Gordy yanks his axe free. The debris collapses. Gordy moves to the firefighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two floors up. I heard screaming... Couldn't get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: takes off. Charges the next flight of stairs. Reaches the fifth floor. Tries to reach six, but there's too much fire. He's beaten back... but not before he hears the FAINT sound of SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy looks down the fifth floor hallway to an apartment door at the end. Between him and the door is the gaping hole in the floor. It's too big to jump. He starts running. He's gonna jump it. Gordy reaches the edge of the hole. Leaps with all he's got. At the same time, he swings the axe, point-first. Slams it into a spot high on the wall, and...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gordy swings over the hole on the axe handle. He hits the other side running. Drives a shoulder into the door at the end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy bursts in. It's an inferno. He looks up. Knocks his axe on the ceiling. Hears desperate POUNDING back. Gordy climbs a table. Starts whacking upward with the axe, attacking the peeling, crumbled plaster overhead. Gordy is trying to hack a hole into the room above, but he's not doing it fast enough. He won't beat the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy calls down to his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the hose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is gone! It could flashover any second!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the goddamn hose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Mike and Junior pass the hose up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy aims the nozzle at the hole he started in the ceiling. Turns it on full jet. Gordy's barely able to hold the hose as the high-pressure stream bites into old, decayed plaster. Bit by bit the ceiling falls away.       Gordy's almost through to the room above, when... Falling debris severs the hose. Gordy's lost pressure. He hasn't broken through. The building's coming down. He's gotta get outta there. Gordy's not going anywhere. Picks up the axe.       Attac the hole again furiously, until finally...

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: breaks through! A small hole, which he quickly widens, to reveal... a terrified Latino family gaping down at him, their room ablaze around them. Gordy reaches up. Speaks to them in Spanglish --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay... Esta bien, esta bien... Come with me... Con mio...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy lowers the family through the floor hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy carries the family's small child outside. He passes the child to its grateful parents, while... The rescued Firefighter sits on a curb looking at a hero and shaking his head in disbelief and admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNE PITT, thirties, reaches out and KILLS the ALARM. She rolls over. The other half of the bed's empty. We hear a CHILD'S VOICE from another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne opens the door to find an exhausted Gordy sitting on the floor with their four-year-old son, MATT. They're building a K'nex spaceship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what we made!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice rocket... That took a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was awake when I got home.   His throat still hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a bad word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feels Matt's forehead.    Gordy's done it already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matt) You better see Dr. Bob. (to Gordy) And this time, no opening fire hydrants to play in till he's completely well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans down and kisses him.      There's passion in it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your shift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) The usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She yawns.    Starts heading out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dreamed I did a triple axel in an ice skating championship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; calls after her) Come back and let me see those legs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy holds Matt in his arms as water pours over them. It's the second child he's held in the last few hours. This one is his, this one is safe at home and unafraid: what a father wants for his child. We see the deep affection Gordy has for his son. He holds Matt tightly, skin to skin, and kisses the boy's wet head... Anne opens the shower door.       She's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Bob can squeeze him in at twelve. I have a patient relations meeting at twelve- fifteen. Can you take him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a game. But yeah, if we do the handoff at the doctor's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, he'll be there... Thanks. (hangs up; to Gordy) Five-of in front of Dr. Bob's. Don't be late. (to Matt) Let's get you out, sweetie. Your father just can't keep you dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads Matt out. Closes the shower door. Gordy sticks his face into the water. Looks back, finds... Two bare butts, Anne's and Matt's, are pressed against the shower door's foggy glass. OFF Gordy, laughing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It appears the entire neighborhood's crammed against the chain-link fence around the court, yelling and cheering as a team of local kids from the NYFD Athletic League plays a team of local kids from the NYPD Athletic League. Gordy's an NYFD coach, exhorts his team at the top of his lungs. The rivalry's intense. The game close.       The noise deafening. Bets are going down. NYFD goes up by one in the final minute. Gordy disses a cop coaching the opposing team. LUIS is one of Gordy's kids. A small but talented fifteen-year-old. Luis steals the ball. Drives for an unguarded lay-up to put the team up by three... And misses. An opponent recovers the ball. The flow shifts toward the other end, but Luis is slow adjusting, devastated at missing the easy "two." Gordy yells at him to defend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luis, get back! Pick up your man!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Luis shakes it off. Hustles back on "D" as his man gets the ball. The opponent's a step ahead. Goes up... And Luis gets there to reject him. The crowd loves it. The BUZZER SOUNDS. NYFD wins.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: In the game's immediate aftermath. NYFD celebrating around them. Gordy's proud of Luis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lose, win, whatever. But one thing we never do. We never, ever give up. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Gordy, smiling at Luis...

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The crowds are gone. Gordy checks his watch and starts off, when a SOUND draws his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luis walks along the inside of the chain-link fence around the court. A neighborhood gangbanger and his crew match Luis step for step outside the fence, rattling the fence, clearly trying to intimidate him.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Gordy stalks walking toward them.    Calls --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing Gordy approach, the gangbanger and crew drift off. Reaching Luis --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told 'em I wouldn't play with 'em anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Gordy sees Luis is scared. And he sees the gangbanger and crew hovering nearby waiting for Gordy to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH the window, we see Gordy delivering Luis to a Latin man, clearly Luis's father and the bodega's owner. We don't hear the words, but we can tell Gordy's complimenting the boy to his dad. Gordy emerges.    Checks his watch.   Whistles up a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic jam on Park Avenue South. Gordy's anxious. Checks his watch. He's late. To the cabbie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try Fifth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne waits on the corner with Matt, playing with his spaceship. She checks her watch. It's five of twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifth Avenue's also a parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. He jams money in the pay dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy exits the cab and takes off running.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: checks her watch again.   She's pissed now. In b.g., a cop leaves his police cart to write a ticket. A caravan of Lincoln Navigators passes Anne and turns east on 68th.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: turns onto 68th. As he runs, he jumps, trying to see Anne and Matt over other pedestrians.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: In b.g., the Navigators pull up at a building flying the Colombian flag. Latin and American men in suits get out of the Navigators.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 68TH
dialogues.text: Gordy dodges pedestrians.     Still trying to get a glimp of Anne and Matt. The cop we saw writing tickets earlier is walking the other way. Gordy nearly collides with him. At the last moment, the traffic cop shuffles Gordy aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy reaches the corner. Sees Anne and Matt. Whistles. In b.g., behind Gordy, we see the cop get into a brown Ford.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE AND MATT
dialogues.text: hear the WHISTLE.     Matt sees Gordy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt waves.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: waves back, shrugs an apology to Anne as he starts across the street, when...

dialogues.speaker: INTENSE FLASH
dialogues.text: suddenly lights up the intersection. In SLOW MOTION:

dialogues.speaker: SHOCK WAVE
dialogues.text: wave rolls up 68th past Madison...

dialogues.speaker: HUGE BALL OF FLAME
dialogues.text: erupts behind Anne and Matt... We hear the ENORMOUS BANG of the explosion...

dialogues.speaker: WINDOWS
dialogues.text: are sucked into millions of fragments, a hailstorm of glass...

dialogues.speaker: GREAT CHUNK OF METAL
dialogues.text: -- an engine block -- flies from the ball of flame...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: instinctively pulls her child to her...

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: sees the engine block tumbling through the air toward his wife and son. His scream is lost in the thunderous ROAR all around.

dialogues.speaker: IN SLOW MOTION
dialogues.text: The engine block is about to hit Anne and Matt, when... A FedEx TRUCK, WINDOWS SHATTERED, SKIDS past, wiping out Gordy's line of sight. When the truck clears... Anne and Matt are gone. The corner's empty.   Just Matt's spaceship, slowly falling to the ground...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: There's a horrible SCREECH. A TAXI SKIDS sideways to avoid the FedEx truck and hits Gordy. He's in the air, tumbling, then smacks to the ground. Gordy looks up, through the smoke and falling debris. Then struggles to his hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne! He tries to stand, then falls down, screaming in pain, a large shard of glass embedded in his leg. People come to help him, but Gordy only cares about finding Anne and Matt. He looks around desperately but can't see them, when... His eyes go to the spaceship, in pieces on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gordy screams out his agony --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooooo!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blast detonated here. Some men from the Navigators are dead. MIKE BRANDT is not. Rises from the devastation, gun in hand, as SIRENS wail in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency personnel - EMS, NYPD, NYFD -- swarm the area. Two white plastic sheets cover two bodies. Across the street, PARAMEDICS work on Gordy's leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna give you a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy's oblivious to the pain.     Shoves him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta help you right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've done all we can for 'em, Gordy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI agent JOE PHIPPS ducks under the police tape.     REG DRAY, a young agent, meets him. As they walk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Device functioned in front of the Colombian Consulate just as a motorcade full of brass arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who were the brass, and why were they here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's talking yet, but it smells high-level. There were Colombians and Americans in the cars. Three of 'em ate it. Guy on the phone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates Brandt, talking on a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- is one of the survivors. Name's Brandt. C.I.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gets Phipps' interest momentarily. Then, as they continue toward the consulate, he notices security cameras on the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the surveillance cameras?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're pulling up the video now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops; looks around) Where's N.Y.P.D. on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know it's ours. They're helping with shoe-leather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phipps' eyes go to the white sheets up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got two dead bystanders, a mother and four-year-old son. The father's over there with a leg wound. (indicates Gordy) Guy's a lieutenant with the New York F.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody talk to him yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been giving him room.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO GORDY
dialogues.text: In b.g., Mike, the veteran firefighter in Gordy's engine company, looks under the sheets with a cop.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Junior puts a gentle hand on Gordy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy looks up him, meets his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Mike are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I was late... They shouldn't have been there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike has walked up, lays a comforting hand on Gordy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You don't need to see 'em that way, Gordo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior spots a news camera crew focusing on Gordy's grief, calls at a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get those goddamn people outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phipps, approaching with Dray, addresses the same cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put that tape out fifty more feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop begins moving the camera crew back.     Phipps continues to Gordy. A Paramedic looks up at Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs to go to the hospital. We can't take that glass out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's not bleeding to death, leave him. He's not moving till they do.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Phipps has heard and understands.      To Dray, re: bodies --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chalk 'em and move 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dray goes. Phipps turns to Gordy and the two firefighters standing with him. Addresses Mike --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get on this quick.   I need to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Mike nods.   To Gordy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pitt, if you can you tell me... What'd you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up; beat) What'd I see? I saw my family die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike puts a restraining hand on Gordy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy didn't do the bombing, Gordo. He's just trying to get the people who did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Gordy eases up.   Then, after a moment, defeated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see anything except the explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Phipps sees that's all he's gonna get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is hard. I'm sorry I had to bother you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phipps goes. Gordy looks over as the bodies of Anne and Matt are placed on gurneys and rolled away. Chalk outlines are all that remain of his family. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna roll you to the hospital now and get that glass out.

dialogues.speaker: PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Walking back to the consulate.    He approaches Brandt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Phipps. F.B.I. Counter- terrorism task force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Brandt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What got this place blown up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have this discussion somewhere else more secure, after I get your clearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it takes. But I got a bomber in the wind. I need everything you can give me, and I need it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy's on a gurney on an I.V., his thigh heavily bandaged. Junior and the rookie, Ronnie, are with him, but there's no chatter -- Gordy's shut down, oblivious to everyone around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is on a cell phone nearby as Sal, the other veteran from the engine company, enters and approaches him. Into the phone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on. Mike turns his attention to Sal, who's clearly blown away by the bad news that brought him here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's he holding up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's shut down... We were hoping they'd keep him here, and he wouldn't have to go home right away, but they're cutting him loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to stay at home with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rookie's taking the first shift. I'm just getting the schedule at the firehouse rearranged now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike goes back to the phone, and Sal crosses to Gordy. He puts a hand on Gordy's shoulder, grips it firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.   Got here as fast as I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy sees him, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it sucks... It really sucks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy can't go there.     Beat.     Sal releases his grip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut's deep, but no major vessels were severed. He's got a load 'o silk holding it all together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Junior, who stepped off to talk to a cop, now comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just came over the police radio... Consulate surveillance cameras caught the bomber in the act. He was disguised as a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy looks over.     What Junior just said has triggered something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I saw him... I saw a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy yanks out his I.V., and starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ.    Gordy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Gordy's already on his feet, already moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta help 'em get the bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-lit, sectioned-off area of the garage secured by a chain-link fence. Phipps enters.      As he passes Dray, already there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long before we have a secure computer network?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour.   They're building it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phipps moves to a FORENSIC EXPERT hovering over a table of small fragments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pieces of a pager oxidized with trace elements of Semtex. Probably the triggering device. They dial it up, probably from a cell phone, and boom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a microchip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... This is the memory chip. I can build it into a working pager and maybe get a number readout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phipps moves to the next work area, where another FORENSIC EXPERT studies video from a consulate surveillance camera.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: in super slow-mo, we see a cop -- the one who later bumped into Gordy -- in front of the consulate. His hat is pulled down over his eyes, almost concealing his tinted glasses. As the cop faces more toward the camera, the expert freeze-frames. To Phipps --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's as much face as we get. He was careful to duck the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run a total analysis. I want to know if this asshole's right or left-handed. I want everything you can get outta this film. Phipps keeps moving, enters an eerie recreation of the blast site. Streets, buildings, etc. are marked out on the garage floor. Pieces of the Navigators rest in front of the area marked "consulate;" parts of an NYPD traffic scooter rest in front of the Navigators; "X's" mark where Anne and Matt were standing. Phipps crosses to another AGENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any helpful information coming outta Colombia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. Sat-Intel hasn't picked up any related data-traffic, either. Dray walks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon Pitt's here. He says he saw a cop at the scene.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Gordy, accompanied by Mike and Ronnie, sits in front of a video monitor. Phipps and Dray look on.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: a police cart pulls up outside the consulate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cart was stolen from the Central Park Precinct yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop gets out of the scooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him. That's the son of a bitch I bumped into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop tickets a vehicle, then walks west out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bomb's in the cart.

dialogues.speaker: PHIPPS
dialogues.text: reverses the video, freeze-frames on the cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think the bomb was triggered by a cell phone. The guy doesn't have one in his hands here. Did you see a cell phone when you ran into him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much time passed between then and the explosion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Seconds... Five, ten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think maybe he got into the brown Ford. You see him then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I cared about was getting to my wife and boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Phipps) Guy still had enough time to get out a phone and dial it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, then, by way of ending it) We might need to call you in again to look at some photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Gordy looks back at the grainy image of the cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I touched him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bagpiper plays "Amazing Grace." REVEAL Gordy holding Matt's small coffin as Anne's is lowered into the ground. Gordy's men are around him, along with many other NYFD personnel, family and friends. A second bagpiper farther away in the cemetery, picks up the song, begins playing it in a round with the first. Matt's coffin is taken from Gordy.    As it is lowered... A third bagpiper, farther away still, begins playing the song with the other two. One by one the first and second bagpipers finish their rounds, until there is just the third -- a haunting, mournful wail off into the distance. And then... There's only silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy stands at an open closet door. He leans in, buries his face in Matt's clothes and smells them. Smells his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is ON LOW, tuned to the NEWS.    Gordy is alone, slumped in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The bombing that left a mother and son dead and New York City numb took on a new dimension today when a notorious Latin American terrorist took credit for the attack.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: has roused from his despondency, TURNS UP the VOLUME as the report (containing visuals) continues --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an e-mail to the New York Times, a Marxist extremist known only as 'The Wolf,' states that the bombing was, quote, 'not an act of terror but an act of war, aimed at stopping your C.I.A. murderers and their fascist puppets from committing further acts of repression against the people of Colombia,' unquote... Two Colombian officials and an American military officer died in last Thursday's blast. Also killed were Anne Pitt, wife of a New York City firefighter, and their only child, four-year-old Matt... The President has vowed that the United States will avenge what he called 'this monstrous act of barbarism and cowardice'... Intelligence sources say the identity and whereabouts of The Wolf remain a mystery. They believe he has worked closely with radical elements in Latin America for more than twenty years and have linked him to numerous terrorist bombings, including the 1983 downing of a Peruvian airliner, which killed forty-two people, eleven of them Americans... The head of the Latin America Indigenous People's Committee, a group known to be sympathetic to the radicals in Colombia, talked to News Six in Queens.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: watches as Ephraim Ortiz-Dominguez a Latin man in his forties, comes on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot speak for The Wolf or his actions. I would only repeat that the leftist guerrillas in Colombia are not terrorists but freedom fighters in a war being waged against them by the U.S. and Colombian governments. Governments who wish only to protect a system that lines the pockets of corrupt politicians and multi-national profiteers. (jump cut)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deaths of the woman and little boy are regrettable, but your government inflicts them all the time. Yugoslavia, Iraq... You call it 'collateral damage'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An FBI SURVEILLANCE TEAM has taken over the office. Three agents work video and audio recording devices. A camera points out the window to a line of storefronts across the street. The lights are on in one building with a sign reading "IPC" (Indigenous People's Committee) The FBI agents listen to live audio from the IPC office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosetta, I said mustard on the side. You'll have to go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what cracks me up about commies? They're all 'equality this, equality that,' and they're all chauvinists. Listen to that fucking guy. What they hear, however, is ROSETTA SCREAM as a DOOR CRASHES open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? GLASS SHATTERS. THINGS are BROKEN.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO MONITORS
dialogues.text: The video monitors show Gordy wrecking the IPC office with a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy smashes office equipment left and right. ORTIZ- DOMINGUEZ and ROSETTA cower as Gordy vents his pent-up, end-of-the-world rage using the bat the way we saw him use a fire axe. Gordy approaches Ortiz-Dominguez with the bat.      Backs up against a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... The FBI agents crash in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pitt! Gordy just stares down at Ortiz-Dominguez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the way to do things. Gordy still doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys're only mouthpieces. Beat.   Then Gordy swings the bat.   Hard.   And... Destroys the computer monitor next to Ortiz-Dominguez. Gordy tosses the bat aside.    To the shaking Latin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that for collateral damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy sits across from Phipps.    Dray is present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ortiz-Dominguez has agreed not to press charges if you make full restitution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already paid. With my family. Beat.   Phipps sees it's pointless to insist.   To Dray -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dray heads out, passing Mike Brandt, who enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy, this is Mike Brandt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pitt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry for your loss... I lost people, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Mike was in the motorcade that day... He's the chief U.S. intelligence officer overseeing Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mr. Pitt, we're gonna get the son-of-a-bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe The Wolf's in hiding in an area of Colombia controlled by the E.L.C., extreme Marxist guerrillas... He thinks he's in a safe haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt lets "thinks" sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's hard for you right now, Mr. Pitt. We're all sorry. But why don't you go home. We're taking care of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Brandt proffers a business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my card. Call me any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy takes it.    Just sits there a long moment, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of twisted people do things like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Brandt and Phipps don't have an answer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NEW YORK TIMES
dialogues.text: Gordy talks to a Latin reporter, ERNIE OROSCO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You interested in the big picture or all the unpleasant details?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My family died because of what's going on down there. I want to know all I can. Orosco searches for a starting point.   Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, basically, the situation in Colombia sucks... As Orosco continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the course of a week: 1. Gordy takes pictures, etc., off a wall in his home. He pins up photos of Anne and Matt at the top of the wall. Beneath them he pins up a large map of Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The government's been fighting different Marxists factions for over thirty-five years. For most of that time, it was winning...

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY
dialogues.text: 2. At the New York Public Library, Gordy uses microfilm files and computer access to the web to search out information on Colombia and The Wolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Suddenly the guerrillas began chopping 'em up. High-tech weapons and equipment, well- trained troops, aggressive hit- and-run tactics, all financed by extortion, kidnapping and collecting taxes from dope growers. It's big money, and they put it to use...

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: 3. Gordy pins up various Colombia-related articles and pictures on the wall, including the surveillance camera s The Wolf from the front page of The New York Post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The government got scared. In 1998, to jump start peace talks, it gave a coalition of guerrilla groups temporary control over much of southern Colombia... The first communist stronghold on an American continent...

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: 4.   Gordy draws a line around the guerrilla zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But there've been few talks and no peace. And the Colombian military can't get near the guerrilla zone, especially around the town of Caguan, where the E.L.C. kicks ass and takes no prisoners...

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: 5.   Gordy circles and labels the ELC-controlled area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And that's where we come in. Supposedly, to help eliminate narcos operating in the guerrilla zone. But some well-informed people think that's just an excuse to hit the guerrillas themselves, since they're wrapped around the drug trade... We're there, we're involved... If we stay, the only real question is which Vietnam War we're gonna have. The one some feel we could've won or the one we lost...

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: 6. Gordy watches a documentary about Colombia which shows rebels, army troops, death squads, firefights, and atrocities and bodies on both sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bottom line? The place is as dangerous as a snakepit. You've got the different guerrilla groups, C.I.A., F.B.I., D.E.A., Colombian military, U.S. military, right- wing death squads -- and the only thing they've all managed to do is destroy a beautiful country and inflict suffering on the real people... Hey, I'm Colombian, and I'll never go back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Gordy's packed wall...

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: As Gordy closes the front door, REVEAL Mike, the firefighter, who's just come in and now stands staring at the wall, clearly whelmed by the level of compulsion this must have required.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't heard from you in a couple days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy's obsessed, totally consumed by his project.      H points at a picture of heavily-armed guerrillas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E.L.C. attack platoon... These assholes kill innocent people all the time in Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy indicates a newspaper article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirteen dead in a bus. (indicates another) A market. Twenty-seven dead. (another) A whole family... Anne and Matt didn't mean shit to them. (indicates The Wolf) Or him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike interrupts, trying to divert him to something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we never turned down free beer, and rookie's buying, you believe that? He certified today, he's off probation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking at wall) Ronnie couldn't find a fire with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yeah.   Let's go tell him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy doesn't react.     Beat.      More serious now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Gordo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy hears the tone. Looks over and meets Mike's eyes, seeing the genuine concern there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We aren't gonna let 'em drink all the beer, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Gordy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV ON in b.g. Gordy's with Mike, Sal, Junior and Ronnie. They've emptied a few pitchers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low on beer, Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I'll get more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and heads for the bar.        To Gordy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what'll be great: when you get back to work with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how long is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Week, two weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrinks say ten more days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking doorknob they put in temporary command...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morgan, the guy from 23, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a jerkoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even makes you look good, Gordo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie yells over from the bar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Gordy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys look over as the bartender TURNS UP the VOLUME on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: we see the President's National Security Advisor step up to a podium to give a statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, at 0700 hours Eastern Daylight Time, a joint United States/Colombian strike force launched a full-scale assault at a base camp of the Army of Colombian Liberation, or E.L.C., in Southern Colombia. The purpose of the mission was to punish the people behind the brutal bombing in New York City ten days ago... We are presently evaluating after-action reports from Special Operations Group, but feel confident that we have accomplished our mission...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers throughout the bar.         Mike quiets them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... At this time, we believe the man responsible for carrying out the New York bombing, the terrorist known as The Wolf, is among the enemy dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big cheers now. Toasts all around. Everyone in the place is happy for Gordy, who sits there a moment trying to absorb the news, then buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dalmatian whizzes on the hydrant outside. Sal plays chess in the open door with the neighbor kid. Ronnie polishes chrome on the truck. Gordy holds up the broken remains of his ice cream maker as Junior looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gone three weeks and this place falls apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The temp lieutenant put it out back, and Art hit it with his truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to Gordy) We're having problems with the portable pump again, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who backed over that?... My tools still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs in your locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figured you guys would've sold my stuff at a yard sale by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art's sleeping. Gordy opens his locker. There are old pictures of Anne and Matt still taped inside. He glances at them quickly, then pulls out his tools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike's channel-surfing again. Gordy goes by the door, carrying his tools and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever stay on one channel long enough to hear what they're saying? Whereupon Mike lands on CNN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a surprise today -- And then we're on another channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back!   Go back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? But Gordy has charged in and grabs the remote from Mike, switches channels back to CNN.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: we see a CNN anchor with an over-the-shoulder graphic showing the still of the cop from the consulate surveillance camera with "The Wolf" superimposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... videotape from the terrorist who calls himself The Wolf... On screen, we now see a homemade video of a masked figure wearing a camo floppy hat and a hunter's mesh face mask with a strange-smiling face painted on it in camo earth tones. The Wolf's body is hidden shadow, the voice digitally altered to a deep bass growl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought you killed me. You didn't. I'm still here... We see Gordy's demeanor shift, retreating to the obsessive, seething hatred he showed before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I swear that for every freedom fighter you killed, ten Americans will die. And I will pick the time and the place. And I will enjoy it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wolf slaps his palm for emphasis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Venceremos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tape ends.    Mike shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy, Quaddafi, that Bin Laden... We never get these assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Gordy, his spark of life suddenly extinguished...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four connected townhouses sit behind gates on a tree- lined street in Georgetown. A sign reads: Latin American Institute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt's on the phone.    He's pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Senator, the failure of one operation shouldn't cause your committee to question financing everything else we're doing down there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DONALD UPDEGRAF, Brandt's number two, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I know it looks bad, and I appreciate your support. Together we'll get it done... Yeah. 'bye. (hangs up; to Updegraf) Without his father's money, that asshole'd be keeping bees for a living... What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy Pitt's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's called every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Updegraf picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pitt, Mr. Brandt'll have to get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy's mood is dark. It's not improved by hearing the bullshit in Updegraf's reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him not to bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams down the phone. Rips up Brandt's business card. He's alone with his frustration, with his rekindled hatred and rage. OFF Gordy, glaring at the photo of The Wolf on his wall...

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMS AREA
dialogues.text: Armed police lead Rottweilers through the newly-arrived passengers. FIND Gordy in line. He wears jeans, polo shirt, Timberlands, carries a backpack. Gordy advances to an IMMIGRATION OFFICER, hands over his documents. The agent studies Gordy's passport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business or pleasure, senor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agent looks up at Gordy.         Looks back at the pa Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One moment, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agent gets the attention of an IMMIGRATION SUPERIOR, and the two of them confer out of earshot a moment. The Superior looks over at Gordy. Then approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you would come with me, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customs Superior closes the door.      Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know who you are, Mr. Pitt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says so right there in my passport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're aware your wife and child were killed in the bombing in New York. (off Gordy's look) We have C.N.N. here, too. (then) It's better for you to visit another country. For your own sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You giving me a choice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But not about staying in Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door, addresses two armed policemen in Spanish. Turning back to Gordy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These men will escort you onto whatever flight you wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out Gordy's passport.     Beat.   Gordy takes it starts out. As he goes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's The Wolf you're after, yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy stops, turns back. He says nothing, but the look on his face speaks volumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Then I've just done you a bigger favor than you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy doesn't respond.    Just turns and goes.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Gordy's flanked by the armed policemen, one with a Rottweiler. As they walk, a PA announcement in Spanish is repeated in English...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Avianco flight 42 to Panama City is now open for boarding... Avianca flight 42 to Panama City is now open for boarding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Gordy, having heard the announcement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The highway terminates here, far short of Colombia. The idea is to inhibit the northbound migration of people and drugs. From this point south lies the Darien Gap, a thick rain forest traversed only by rough trail. A cab with a Panama City logo pulls up at road's end. Gordy gets out with the Panamanian CAB DRIVER. The Cab Driver indicates a Panamanian man waiting there with a .9mm on his hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cousin, Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever and Gordy exchange nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far's Colombia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cab Driver indicates distant mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond those mountains... The trail is very dangerous, but do not worry, Ever will get you there... You can pay him then... You can pay me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy pulls out his wallet, pays the Cabbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gracias, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Driver gets back inside the cab.    Out the window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Que la vaya bien.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives off. Gordy looks to Ever. Ever smiles, motions him to follow, then turns south and starts walking. As Gordy falls in behind...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Gordy and Ever pass through pristine tropical rain forest.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR STREAM
dialogues.text: rushing fiercely through the jungle, Ever uses his machete to cut two lengths of bamboo. He hands one to Gordy and indicates how they'll ford the stream. Gordy nods, then follows Ever's lead into the perilous, belly- deep water. They struggle to maintain their balance, even with the sticks. When they reach the opposite bank, Ever signs okay to Gordy and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER CARCASS
dialogues.text: They pass the carcass of a crashed and burned-out helicopter, when... Two dangerous-looking men armed with assault rifles step out of nowhere onto the path ahead of Gordy and Ever. Gordy and Ever stop. Gordy glances at Ever. Ever's focused on the men and clearly doesn't like what he sees. Gordy looks back. The armed men advance toward them carefully, rifles in the ready position. Gordy watches them approach, wondering who they are and what they're going to do. Ever, frightened, takes a half-step back, then swings the length of bamboo fast and hard, and...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He smashes it into the base of Gordy's head, knocking Gordy out. The men run up. One man covers Gordy, while Ever and the other man rifle his pack and toss his pockets. They take his passport, wallet, and an NYFD T-shirt. And then they're gone.

dialogues.speaker: HUMMINGBIRD
dialogues.text: Hovering over Gordy as he comes to.     As it flies off..

dialogues.speaker: 92A GORDY
dialogues.text: sits up. Feels the bloody lump on his head. It hurts, but it's not serious. He searches his pockets and backpack, realizes the passport and wallet are missing. Gordy stands. Looks around. He's alone.      He's in the jungle... He keeps heading south.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Gordy trudges on. The thick jungle's hot and humid, full of STRANGE SOUNDS and shadowy animal movements. Gordy's going uphill, when he rounds a bend in the trail, and... He meets a man coming the other way. Alarm gives way to the realization that the man is followed by a number of people, including women and children. As they pass Gordy, it's apparent they're refugees from their haunted expressions and crude backpacks heavy with possessions... Gordy addresses the passing people.     Indicates where h standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aqui?   Colombia?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one replies. Then a small COLOMBIAN GIRL comes up and gets his attention. She runs back up the trail a short distance and stops. She draws a line in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jumps backward over the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panama... Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. At the sound of a sharp WHISTLE, however, she runs back quickly, passing Gordy and rejoining her family. Her father hands her a machete and a Zippo lighter, says something to her. Whereupon the little girl returns to Gordy and holds the items out to him. Beat. Gordy takes them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gracias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl runs back again, and Gordy watches the refugees disappear around the bend. Then turns back uphill and approaches the line the little girl drew in the dirt. Looks down at it. Crossing over means he walks into a world dangerous enough to cause these people to flee for their lives, and... Just as Gordy charged into the fire-engulfed tenement past a tide of more sensible rats going the other way, he now steps over the line and advances into Colombia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the rain forest of Darien continues in Colombia. Darkness sets in as Gordy follows the trail downhill. night, the JUNGLE'S EVEN NOISIER. When... EVERYTHING GOES QUIET. Gordy slows. And suddenly, AUTOMATIC WEAPONS begin to POP somewhere. Not close, but not far, either. A FEW BURSTS, some SINGLE SHOTS -- the call and response of an ambush -- and then SILENCE. And then the nighttime JUNGLE NOISES return. As Gordy walks on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is already cooking the jungle as Gordy reaches a break in the trees, sees a small town ahead.

dialogues.speaker: NEARBY
dialogues.text: Gordy has left the trail. He lowers his pants just enough to expose his injured thigh. A bandage covers the wound made by the glass shard. Gordy unwraps the bandage, revealing... A wad of cash is hidden inside, along with a photo of Anne and Matt. A long, livid scar marks the wound. Gordy studies the photo of Anne and Matt a moment, then removes some cash from the wad and re-wraps the money and photo inside the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON TRAIL
dialogues.text: Gordy heads into the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the colorful, wretchedly overcrowded buses that ply Colombia's back-country roads. As the chiva jolts and shudders over the dirt road, Gordy sleeps. He's an object of some curiosity -- not only a gringo, but a virtual Gulliver in comparison to the small-statured Colombians pressed in around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sprawling farm/estate deep in the countryside. Beyond the hacienda, we see a military compound containing tents and three heavily camouflaged helicopter shelters. A recently arrived Light Observation Helicopter (LOH) sits on a chopper pad with its rotors still turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of manned hi-tech command-and-control and surveillance equipment. A Colombian military operations officer, ROCHA, waits with an aide. Brandt arrives with Updegraf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find your fucking leak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. And it could be your fucking leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All due respect, Noel, it's not likely... And we don't need the whole world looking into what we're doing down here... We find the son-of-a-bitch again, we're bypassing protocols...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Updegraf has had papers handed to him and interrupts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands a paper to Brandt.    Brandt reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rocha) The man whose wife and son died in New York. One of your units found his passport and credit cards on some gunrunners near Panama. Gunrunners say they left him alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, he thinks he can get The Wolf himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have too much time and too many people invested to have a loose cannon walking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; hands papers to Rocha) Throw out the net. Have him picked up... Just make sure no one kills him.

dialogues.speaker: EXPLOSION
dialogues.text: Boom!   An ENORMOUS EXPLOSION.      And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy bolts awake from the nightmare with a scream. He looks around at the startled faces in the crowded bus, unsure where he is for a moment before he gets his bearings. The dream lingers, depressing him.

dialogues.speaker: AHEAD OF CHIVA
dialogues.text: An oncoming bus flashes its headlights. As the buses pass, the ONCOMING DRIVER yells to Gordy's chiva driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspecion militar. Chequeo de papeles.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CHIVA
dialogues.text: keeps going. Gordy's chiva slows to a crawl, and the Driver calls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspecion militar. Chequeo de papeles. Various passengers gather their things and begin to disembark in a hurry. To anyone who'll answer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Habla Ingles?... Que pasa? A MAN IN A YANKEES CAP is among the people getting off. He answers in accented English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a military checkpoint up the road. They inspect everyone's papers.

dialogues.speaker: BUS
dialogues.text: starts to pick up speed again. Gordy gets off just in time. To the Man in the Yankees Cap --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are all of you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We walk around. The man heads into the forest.   Beat.   Gordy follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Man in the Yankees Cap as they walk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of these people have papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some have the wrong papers. Some have none... The man puts a finger to his lips, hushing Gordy. They've come abreast of the checkpoint, which can be seen in the distance through the trees. Colombian soldiers have the chiva blocked as they perform their inspection. The chiva's DIESEL GROWLS loudly. When suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: FIGURES
dialogues.text: We see figures moving in the forest between the group and the checkpoint. And then... The forest erupts in a deafening fusillade of AUTOMATIC WEAPONS FIRE being directed at the soldiers at the checkpoint. In the same instant, an RPG takes out a Colombian Army humvee in a bright, fiery EXPLOSION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alsuelo!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The man pulls Gordy down as the group hits the dirt.   Th GUNFIRE continues. On the ground, to Gordy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guerrilleros. The attack rages furiously for twenty seconds, then wanes to sporadic GUNFIRE. Other WEAPONS are FIRING now, too -- clearly the Army is finally mounting a defense. And then...

dialogues.speaker: FOREST
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of PEOPLE CRASHING through the forest. They're running toward Gordy and the group. The CRASHING GETS CLOSER. And now Gordy begins to hear the BREATHLESS PANTING of the guerrillas in retreat. BOOTS THUD past Gordy's head. When suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: One of the running guerrillas trips over Gordy and goes sprawling. The guerrilla, wearing the motley uniform of an irregular soldier, whips a look back, and... Gordy finds himself staring into the battle-hardened eyes of a fierce young woman. In a heartbeat... The woman jumps back to her feet, and   joins her comrade laying down a suppressing FIRE at the   soldiers. Spent cartridges rain down around Gordy, as   the AK-47 ON FULL AUTO chops loudly over his head. And    then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guerrillas are gone. The Man in the Yankees hat hauls Gordy up, yells --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is in the greatest danger now -- caught between the fleeing guerrillas and the soldiers, who are giving chase and will shoot anyone or thing in front of them. Everyone in the group scrambles to his or her feet and begins to run. And... Soldiers do notice them and begin to FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: FOLIAGE
dialogues.text: BULLETS SHRED the foliage around Gordy, whipping past his head... He and others keep running. A man goes down when a BULLET BITES into his leg. Gordy slows, but the Man in Yankees Cap won't let him stop to help. Slams him hard on his back. Keeps pushing Gordy forward. A few moments later, we hear M-16's on FULL AUTO back where they left the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His trouble is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The powerful TORRENT ROARS through the forest. Gordy and the others reach the near bank, where the path drops into the water to reappear on the opposite bank. The Man in the Yankees Cap is in the lead. He plunges into the fast water up to his waist. Gordy and the rest splash in behind, struggling to cross against the swift current. The Man in the Yankees Cap reaches the far bank. Takes two steps, and...

dialogues.speaker: EXPLOSION
dialogues.text: BOOM!   An EXPLOSION rips into him.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY AND OTHERS
dialogues.text: stop mid-stream, but one of the group, a young woman, believing the blast was caused by the pursuing military, continues struggling to cross. An OLDER MAN looks, sees the blast-hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy realizes the old man's saying "land mine."   To the young woman --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy moves to catch her.   Just manages to stop her as she reaches the far bank.   Gordy points to where the lan mine detonated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mina... Mina...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Slowly, the terrified young woman responds to the strong, calm tone of command in Gordy's voice and the unpanicked, reassuring look on his face. Gordy brings her back to the group, which fights to stand in the rushing river. He indicates for them to hold hands for stability. Motions for them to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alto.

dialogues.speaker: GORDY
dialogues.text: leaves the group in the middle of the river. The GUNFIRE is now FAR-OFF AND SPORADIC. He crosses to the water's edge on the far bank. Pulls the Zippo from his pack and leans over. Uses the flame to illuminate the mud and rock immediately in front of him. Scratches lightly at the ground with the machete, searching for mines. Finds n in that spot. And steps onto it. Searching the ground and scratching at it with the machete before each step, Gordy inches toward the Man in the Yankees Cap. Three steps from the river...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He finds a small, round anti-personnel mine the size of a hockey puck. He inches past it. Moves past another. And another. To the writhing Man in the Yankees Cap --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move... Don't move...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Gordy reaches him. One of the man's legs is missing below the knee. He's bleeding from various other wounds as well. Gordy uses the Zippo to inspect the area for more mines. Then kneels in a footprint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be okay... You'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a bandanna from the man and ties a tourniquet around his thigh. By way of distracting him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guerrilla bastards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... Military... To stop guerrillas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Gordy finishes the tourniquet, when he sees...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: has left the group and emerged from the river in a different place to avoid the mines. Gordy's eyes go to something glistening in front of the young man -- a taut nylon line ten inches off the ground. The kid's about to hit it. Gordy shouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!   Alto!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man hears the alarm in Gordy's voice and stops... But not before he plants his next step, and... The trip wire bows against his shin, and... Gordy ducks, covers the Man in the Yankees Cap, and... Nothing happens. The young man just stands there, frozen in position, his leg still bowing the line.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Using the Zippo again to light his way, Gordy advances to the young man. He follows the trip wire to where a Coca- Cola can hangs from a nearby tree. On closer inspection, Gordy can see the can is sleeved around a grenade. There's no pin in the grenade. The can keeps the grenade's arming spoon in place. The trip wire's designed to yank the can off, allowing the grenade to explode at chest level... And the can's almost off. Gordy burns through the monofilament trip wire. Then carefully slides the Coke can back over the grenade.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN YANKEES CAP
dialogues.text: When Gordy returns, the man's dead.    OFF Gordy, looking down at the NY logo on the cap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy sees a sign for a town as the chiva rumbles along. He pulls out his map.

dialogues.speaker: MAP
dialogues.text: Gordy finds the town, which lies along a river. He traces a road from the town. The road runs south through the town of Mompos, and eventually reaches Caguan, the ELC capital.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: A COLOMBIAN WOMAN is looking over Gordy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No autobusses para este lugar. Solamente el barco en el rio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans over, traces the river, which also runs to Caguan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El rio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FERRY'S WHISTLE TOOTS.    Lines are cast off.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Two plainclothes federales have been watching the ferry load and now relax their vigil. One man holds a Xerox of Gordy's passport photo. The other bites into an empanada, which breaks open and spills its contents down the front of his shirt. His partner finds it funny. He doesn't. And while their attention's occupied... Gordy hurries by, oblivious to the federales' presence, and just manages to hop onto the ferry as it pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ferry's the only means of travel south, and it's packed. Gordy picks his way through. The only other gringo on the boat is a geek in a plaid shirt and gimme hat that says "Deerborn." The geek, PHILIP ARMSTRONG, looks like a talker, and Gordy tries to avoid eye contact. He's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, yo, dude, here's a seat, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's okay --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Armstrong's already throwing a bag off the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping for someone I could communicate with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Gordy hasn't moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only room's at the back near the bano, and I'd advise against it, unless you like poop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Gordy sits.   Immediately --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip Armstrong. Assiniboia, Sasketchewan, Canada. (indicates his hat) Deerborn Heavy Equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Gordy Pitt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, howya doing? I love Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Austria.   American now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love America. Never been to Austria. Where from in America would that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like New York City. Buildings're too big. What kinda work you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) Coffee. I buy beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't drink caffeine. Makes my stomach do the rumba. I like that commercial guy with the sombrero and the mule, though. Headed upstream, eh? Where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caguan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You've never been to Caguan, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause no one in their right mind would ever go back. Caguan's in the guerrilla zone run by the E.L.C. E.L.C. as in 'Extra Loathsome Communists.' They don't care, and they kill. I'm going there myself. But I have a 'get outta jail free' card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong doffs his cap, undoes a safety pin securing a card inside the crown. Shows it to Gordy. Sotto --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E.L.C. travel pass. I can go anywhere I want. (by way of explanation) Everyone needs equipment fixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong carefully returns the card to the hat. And now his voice takes on a noticeably more measured tone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't have one of these, you don't want to be up there, Gordy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Gordy's contemplating the warning, when his eyes go to a small, sleepy boy standing nearby on the cramped deck, leaning against his father. Gordy reaches over and taps the boy. The boy looks over. Shrinks away at the sight of the large gringo. The father notices and looks at Gordy, who stands, indicates his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Por favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father's also apprehensive, doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Con mucho gusto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the father accepts, sits down with the sleepy boy on his lap. Nods his thanks at Gordy, who then gazes down at the son. A kid about Matt's age. Armstrong recognizes the look of a caring dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got kids, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF Armstrong, as Gordy walks away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Colombian armed man wearing guerrilla uniforms bearing a distinctive ELC patch are walking a trail, when the man in front notices something odd. He stops. Leads the other man back a few steps. Looks into the foliage along the trail. Something doesn't seem right. He extends his AK-47. Prods a hump of greenery with the rifle butt, and in a flash... The greenery suddenly transforms into two men wearing face-paint and full-body military camouflage gear and pointing twin cocked-and-locked CAR-15 assault rifles at the heads of the startled guerrillas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt stubs a butt as a Colombian SOG group does killer training nearby. Updegraf opens the door. To Brandt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Rocha's infiltration teams just radioed in... We got our big break...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordy stands along the rail looking out at the lush, beautiful countryside sliding past. Armstrong joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little kid and I had a nice, long snooze... We're almost to Mompos. (gazing out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better be.    A lotta people're dying for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks overboard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, I haven't noticed one darn body floating downstream this whole trip, have you? Gordy doesn't respond.    Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking... Maybe we could travel together into Caguan. You could show me around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass is only good for one person, if that's your idea, which I think it is... Besides, I can't risk traveling around up there in the company of a big gringo with a dumb-ass cover story about coffee beans. Gordy looks over.   Armstrong smiles back.     Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got money. I'll buy the pass from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've worked too hard for it. And you don't have that kind of money on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be getting some life insurance money --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) It's all cash and carry down here, Gordy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FERRY WHISTLE TOOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mompos... You want to have some fun, we'll hook up later. I always schedule a stopover. To sample the local wares and such. (winks) Life can be what you make it here on the frontier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta get off the boat anyway. Mompos is the last stop. From here into the guerrilla zone you can only travel by panga... If you change your mind, I'll be at the Tropicale later. It's a gringo bar. Just follow the cockroaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They see the beginnings of Mompos. Two 4x4 trucks are parked on the riverbank. Lean, clean-cut men in jeans, tight shirts, cowboy boots and sunglasses lean on the truck and watch the ferry pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sicarios. Death squads. Avoid those dudes at all costs.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The ferry pulls up to the dock. The dock street is a culture clash of shanty bars and Amazon Indian traders, of big-wheel SUVs and mule carts. There's a definite air of menace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Federales are looking for someone. Gordy follows Armstrong's look to two plain-clothes federales, one fat and one thin, standing near the dock watching the boat pull up. When Gordy glances back, Armstrong is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
